title: Question 73

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-week history of pruritic rash on several areas, including the hands. There is no facial involvement.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is scabies (

), an intensely pruritic skin condition that presents with papules and burrows on the fingers and web spaces. Other common areas of involvement are the breasts, wrists, axillae, waistline, genitalia, and ankles. Scabies typically spares the face and scalp in adults. Pruritus is usually worse at night. Scabies is caused by

, which lives in the human epidermis. Skin-to-skin contact, including sexual transmission, is the primary mode of transmission. Outbreaks are common in families, institutional settings, and the homeless population due to its highly contagious nature. Crusted scabies, a form of scabies with a significantly higher mite load (thousands versus 5-15 mites in typical scabies), presents with widespread psoriasiform and hyperkeratotic lesions; it is more common in immunocompromised patients.
